subject: Re: [junit] setUp versus constructors

messageBody:
Kent Beck wrote:

> Apparently I haven't stated this strong enough in the past. You should
> assume that each test method will be run with a fresh test method in JUnit.
> This has been part of the architecture from the beginning and I don't see
> any reason to change it. The principle behind this choice is that tests
> should be order-independent. Running with separate instances supports
> independence.

That's fine. As I think about it, there's still another reason not to
initialize objects in the constructor: test instance creation happens
well before the test runs, so if too much initialization happens in the
constructor, one might run out of memory before running any tests. Also,
this could wreak havoc with test resources. Imagine what happens if each
test tries to grab (and hold) a database connection!

So it's good news: there's still at least one very good reason why
initializing in the constructor is different from using setUp(). I guess
I've been right for the wrong reason. :)

Thanks for the clarification.

Still, seeing as NUnit pools test instances, I think it's worth not
relying on JUnit creating separate test instances.

Take care.
